channel.title: First C++ Program

item.title: First C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“bakatool, post:25, topic:196257”]I suggest dont use the << for output it could get confusing you its really not needed to be like that just use

printf("You logged in as %s. \n ", username);

looks much nicer to me.

would say
You logged in as bakatool.
for example

actually in your case its easy any way you do it so it doesn’t matter but when u start doing casting from one to another it will give you tons of warnings even errors in some cases without printf[/quote]

Sorry, but using printf is wrong. The function printf is a legacy function from C, which should always be avoided, unless there is an extremely strong reason for a particular case that suggests otherwise.

Printf is a variadic function, which tend to be completely type unsafe (And printf is, indeed, type unsafe) besides other problems. There is hardly ever a reason to use a variadic function in C++ at all.

Output through streams (Done through overloaded << operators), on the other hand, are the way to go, and are type-safe.

The reason why you are getting errors while using these is, most probably, and somewhat ironically, the best reason for you to use them.

If you choose the wrong type with printf, it is most likely to corrupt the stack, to lead to UB, or even to cause an exploitable vulnerability. If you choose the wrong type with streams (Which is a lot less likely, seeing how the type is automatically deduced), the program won’t compile, which means you will be able to correct the error in seconds.

Read full topic

@Mopman wrote:

If you already know a programming language or at least have the ability to think logically to some degree, I’d recommend "Accelerated C++ (Practical Programming by Example). 'Tis a good book.

item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“zstars, post:17, topic:196257”]Bjarne Stroustroup’s is a very good book, though it will only be useful if you know both C and an object oriented language already. It is a somewhat technical description of the language.

The other two are very good too, though they will only be of use after you know some C++. They mostly contain individual solutions for common pitfalls, wrong designs, not-do’s, etc.[/quote]
I’ve read that book several times, cover to cover, and it really is quite insightful, despite my copy being over 15 years old.

item.title: First C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:19, topic:196257”]Your code is fine except for

system("pause");

You shouldn’t ever do that, instead if you want that kind of functionality you can do this:

string dummy; cout << "Press any key to continue. "; cin >> dummy; [/quote]

Ya’ll know that the problem I have is for many years I’ve been using computers I can’t find the ‘any’ key.

Read full topic

item.title: First C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Your code is fine except for

system("pause");

You shouldn’t ever do that, instead if you want that kind of functionality you can do this:

string dummy;
cout << "Press any key to continue. ";
cin >> dummy;

Read full topic

item.title: First C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I would have to recommend against reading through the entirety of the Stroustrup book, just because it will induce suicide in otherwise healthy individuals.

It’s an awesome book, but personally I treat it as a reference

Read full topic

item.title: First C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“unlimitedorb, post:14, topic:196257”][quote author=zstars link=topic=260822.msg2165654#msg2165654 date=1207511219]
If you really wanna learn C++, get a good e-book, such as “Accelerated C++”.
[/quote]

This summer I plan on making my way through Bjarne Stroustroup’s “The C++ Programming Language” as well as Scott Meyer’s “Effective C++” and “More Effective C++”. I’ve been told that it’s quite an effective path to take from a guy who works at Google…

EDIT: Removed “that” being mentioned twice in a row haha[/quote]

Bjarne Stroustroup’s is a very good book, though it will only be useful if you know both C and an object oriented language already. It is a somewhat technical description of the language.

The other two are very good too, though they will only be of use after you know some C++. They mostly contain individual solutions for common pitfalls, wrong designs, not-do’s, etc.

Read full topic

item.title: First C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @super_OLDACCOUNT super_OLDACCOUNT
item.description:
@super_OLDACCOUNT wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:10, topic:196257”][quote author=Cheese_Police link=topic=260822.msg2163633#msg2163633 date=1207445096]

You could of also used an array instead of using strings.

Why? If you’re going to use C++, you might as well use the STL to its fullest. C-Style strings in C++ aren’t always the best thing to use.

You, don’t even check if the use is right.

If this was actually a login system, you would need to make sure there is an existent username.

Check the user, then the password.

Then use an array as Baros said, for the members. That way, more than one person can be logged into.

I don’t think he meant keeping multiple users in an array, I think he meant using character arrays (C-Style strings).

STL is standard template library, i thinks u meant to say ‘standard library’

Yes, sorry.
[/quote]
dont apologise, just say you meant to say use a vector instead of an array![/quote]

lol haha

Read full topic
